author: mayar
title: NASA discovered comet to shine past Earth this weekend
text: A comet just discovered last year by observers will whizz past Earth from 44 million miles away but leave a trail of dust and gases visible to the naked eye, NASA said. Comet Tsuchinshan-Atlas will make its closest approach to Earth on Saturday and won't be back for about 80,000 years, the space agency said. It is about two miles in diameter and its tail extends millions of miles. Bill Cooke, of NASA's Meteoroid Environment Office at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., said the comet will appear in the sky like a fireball. "It's not going to zing across the sky like a meteor," Cooke said, according to CNN. "It will just appear to hang there, and it will slowly change position from night to night. If you can see [the comet] with your unaided eye, [using] the binoculars will knock your socks off." It was discovered by the Purple Mountain Observatory in China and the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System, ATLAS, telescope in South Africa. Scientists believe the comet was formed from the Oort Cloud, a spherical shell that surrounds the solar system. "Bright comets are very rare and are usually newcomers to the inner solar system," Cooke said.

author: Ben Mitchell
title: Code Blue issued in NYC as freezing temperatures arrive
text:
WPIX New York City, NY Code Blue issued in NYC as freezing temperatures arrive Ben Mitchell Thu, January 2, 2025 at 8:26 PM UTC 1 min read
Code Blue issued in NYC as freezing temperatures arrive NEW YORK (PIX11) — The unusually warm stretch at the end of 2024 is officially over, with frigid winter temperatures settling in to start the new year.
Overnight temperatures into Friday are expected to sink below freezing, prompting the Department of Homeless Services to issue a Code Blue.
More Local News
Wind gusts will also make air temperature feel even colder. Forecasts suggest it may feel like 20 degrees outside by early Friday morning.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Code Blue is in effect until 8 a.m. Friday. Shelters and drop-in centers will be available city-wide for the homeless and those seeking shelter. No one will be denied shelter during a Code Blue.
The NYCDHS will deploy outreach teams to assist homeless individuals. If you encounter a homeless person in the cold, please call 311, and an outreach team will be sent to that location.
More information on homeless assistance can be found online or on the 311 app.
Ben Mitchell is a digital content producer from Vermont who has covered both local and international news since 2021. He joined PIX11 in 2024. See more of his work here .

author: Scroll Staff
title: Madhya Pradesh: Four arrested for allegedly killing cow, homes razed
text:
[state news](//scroll.in/topic/55654/state-news)
Madhya Pradesh: Four arrested for allegedly killing cow, homes razed
Hindutva groups had staged a protest demanding that the homes of the four accused persons be demolished.
Authorities in Madhya Pradesh’s Agar Malwa district on Tuesday razed the homes of persons accused of harming a cow earlier this week. The cow subsequently
died from the injuries.
On Monday, four men, identified as Durga Shankar Gujjar, Rahul Gujjar, Razzaq Khan and Sonu Mansuri, allegedly assaulted a cow near the district’s Sangakhedi village. The cow had reportedly damaged their crops.
Satyendra Bairwa, the deputy collector of the district, told Scroll that a first information report was filed in the Barod police station under Section 429 (mischief by killing or maiming cattle) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 11 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 1960. They have been arrested.
The alleged killing of the cow triggered widespread protests by Hindutva groups. The protestors had
blocked a highway for more than four hours during their protest, Siasat reported. They demanded that the homes of the four persons be demolished.
A day later, the houses of at least three accused were partially demolished.
However, Bairwa claimed that the demolitions were in connection with a separate case of illegal construction and that the action was not linked to the first information report against them for alleged cruelty against the cow.
In recent years, there has been a growing trend of civic authorities in Bharatiya Janata Party-ruled states demolishing ostensibly illegal properties of those accused of crime. There are no provisions in Indian law that provide for demolishing property as a punitive measure.
Also read:
Why isn’t India’s judiciary acting to stop the spate of illegal demolitions across the country? The BJP’s ‘bulldozer justice’ targets oppressed communities – and has no legal basis

author: VNExplorer
title: Vietnam Veteran Who Battled Terminal Cancer Alone Honored With a Hero’s Burial in Massachusetts
text:
Vietnam Veteran Who Battled Terminal Cancer Alone Honored With a Hero’s Burial in Massachusetts ‘May God bless Charlie Connolly, and all who took the time to Stand for Charlie. Today, we were his family and now, he is finally home,’ State Rep. Steve Xiarhos wrote in a tribute Published |Updated
Zachary Rogers
Hundreds gathered to honor Army Veteran Charles “Charlie” Connolly. State Representative Steve Xiarhos/Facebook
Dozens of strangers and one long-lost friend gathered Friday to honor a Vietnam veteran who has passed away after battling terminal cancer alone.
Army Veteran Charles “Charlie” Connolly, 78, was homeless and had no family at the time of his death on Dec. 18, according to Massachusetts State Rep. Steve Xiarhos. For that reason, the public was invited to attend Connolly’s funeral at the Massachusetts National Cemetery in Bourne. “Hundreds” showed up, Xiarhos says.
“Charlie’s story is a powerful reminder of the challenges many of our veterans face after their service,” Xiarhos said in a Facebook post. “His journey, marked by courage and resilience, ended in the compassionate care of the Veterans Affairs Hospice Unit in Brockton. Despite the lack of family by his side, Charlie’s spirit was never alone.”
Xiarhos, who says he is a Gold Star father, adds that he understands “the pain of loss and the importance of remembrance.”
“My own journey of grief has taught me that we, as a community, must be the family for those who have none,” Xiarhos added. “In honoring Charlie, we not only pay tribute to his life and service but also uphold our duty to support and remember every veteran who has served our nation.”
Connolly was buried in the state’s national cemetery among 78,000 other heroes in what was a full military funeral according to the state representative. After hearing about Connolly’s passing and funeral on the local news, an old friend of the veteran was able to reach out and attend the service, even receiving Connolly’s burial flag, Boston 25 News reports.
“As we laid Charlie to rest in this hallowed grounds… let his memory be a beacon that guides our actions in supporting our veterans,” Xiarhos said in his post. “May God bless Charlie Connolly, and all who took the time to Stand for Charlie. Today, we were his family and now, he is finally home.”
View post on Twitter
